I have to say I dislike the “poisonous” discourse. It just requires your derived products to be open source too, which is utterly unproblematic if you are devoted to open source.
It’s worth noting that although Julia itself is (and should be) MIT that does not imply that the package ecosystem must be (and I’m pretty sure <@U6795JH6H> has articulated this explicitly).

text:
Outside of proprietary development, for most things Julia the MIT license does well for us.
Copyleft is a very heavy requirement -- and it disrupts any opportunity for situation appropriate rights control.  I have not read the MPL recently.  Last I did, it felt like an admirable attempt to climb out from the jungle unintended GPL consequences, yet rooted in the GPL nonetheless.  The overwhelming adoption of OpenSource software is the result of software tectonics and widespread conversancy more than of GPL (in the sense that the GPL could have been structured differently and the adoption would still have occured).

text:
To me copyleft is almost a pyramid scheme.

If I write open source software I want it to result in benifits to people as possible.

So option 1:
I release it under a u restrictive licence like MIT.
100% of people who want software to do the thing I made can use it, and that is great.
High direct benifits

If I release it GPL.
Then maybe 30% of people can't use it because they can't open source their thing. So they have to write software from a scratch. But
Maybe 1% of users end up open sourcing their thing in order to use mine.
So now the benifit I caused it to 70% of my potential users, and to a whole to of extra downstream people.
Lower direct benifit. But maybe higher total benifit.

Which feels to me to be kinda dodgy way to count.
Direct benefits I cause is more important as a measure to me.

text:
> I thought it was copyleft itself which is "poisonous"
Part of that is due to local legislation.

E.g. EU law has various copyright exemptions to enable interoperability that apply regardless of licence. This is why, for example, you can link GPL2 code in a project distributed under GPL3, despite the FSF claiming they're incompatible (according to <https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/eupl> anyway)

text: I think one bad thing with GPL is that (what I’ve heard is that) even looking at the source code and then later writing code for a similar application could be seen as derived. So if I’m going to look at GPL’d source code I have to think I’m never going to want to write commercial code in this area. To me that’s a big restriction (even when I was a PhD student and basically everything I did was open source) because I didn’t/don’t know what I’ll want to do later on, and even if I never end up writing commercial code in that area, I don’t like carrying that restriction around for the rest of my life. (Which is also why NDAs suck, because they are usually super open ended).
